title: Veronica Maggio... Behemoth?
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090619091845im_/http:/typophile.com/files/veronica_maggio_4233.png)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090619091845im_/http:/typophile.com/files/veronica_maggio_4233.png)
  
Anyone knows this one here. First thought was of Dave Wests Behemoth, perhaps with an outline?? Or is there another similar font that i just failed to recognize. Giza??  
Thanks in advance.
author: Gregers™

comments.content:
Giza doesn’t have a serif on the middle arm of the E, but I think your [Behemoth](http://web.archive.org/web/20090619091845/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/atbehemoth/) suggestion is a good choice. A little extra stroke thickness would do it, I think. [Quadra 57](http://web.archive.org/web/20090619091845/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/berthold/quadra-57-bq/) was the other font I looked at, but the serifs are not bracketed.

- Mike Yanega

Hi Mike  
Thank you. I think it must be a Behemoth treatment.

Have a look at [Rio Grande](http://web.archive.org/web/20090619091845/http:/www.identifont.com/show?8Q4) by Nick Curtis or [Champ Ultra](http://web.archive.org/web/20090619091845/http:/www.identifont.com/show?E5D) by Bob Alonso, too.

Rio Grande is a bit more condensed than the sample, but Champ Ultra looks very close.It would be hard to tell it from the sample, I think. Good find Renko.

- Mike Yanega

Thank you Rainer.  
Think you nailed it there with Champ Ultra.
